A "metric group" is a group GGG, whose underlying set is a metric space, and whose metric is bi-invariant, i.e. each translation is an isometry, and inversion x↦x−1x\mapsto x^{-1}x↦x−1 is also an isometry.

One can define a functor UUU from the category of metric groups to the category of metric spaces that forgets the group structure. I am convinced UUU is a right adjoint (nevertheless it is a very abstract argument that convinced me so: see theorem 3.8 here, so I might be missing something, or I might be considering the wrong choice of morphisms to apply this theorem).

How to describe the left adjoint to UUU?

In simple terms: given a metric space (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) I would like to put a metric on the free group on XXX with the property that whenever GGG is a metric group, nonexpansive maps f:X→Gf : X \to Gf:X→G correspond bijectively to nonexpansive group homomorphisms fˉ:FX→G\bar f : FX \to Gfˉ​:FX→G.

You might think that there is a canonical choice for the restriction of the metric to the generators, but suppose that the original metric space is unbounded (take the affine real line with its usual metric, say). Suppose d(x,e)=cd(x,e) = cd(x,e)=c. Then in order for the metric on the generators to coincide with the usual metric on R\RR, we must have d(x,y)−c≤d(e,y)d(x,y) - c \leq d(e,y)d(x,y)−c≤d(e,y) by the triangle inequality, which means that elements which are more than 2c2c2c away from xxx must be increasingly distant from the identity element. This asymmetry seems strange to me. Maybe you're considering a more flexible class of metric spaces (eg one where infinite distance is allowed?)

If you do allow infinite distances, then I expect the identity element will be infinitely far from the generators and the metric structure on the remaining elements will be determined by the free multiplication and inversion structure on the group.

Using the equations x−1⋅x⋅y=y=y⋅x⋅x−1x^{-1}\cdot x \cdot y = y = y \cdot x\cdot x^{-1}x−1⋅x⋅y=y=y⋅x⋅x−1 and (x−1)−1=x(x^{-1})^{-1} = x(x−1)−1=x, one has that all translations and inversions must be isomorphisms in Met\mathbf{Met}Met. Hence, a metric group is just a group in Met\mathbf{Met}Met.

Then, Mardare et al. give an almost explicit construction of the free object using quantitative equational logic. In short, you construct the free group as usual andthe distance between any two words is given by the smallest distance that can be derived in their logic with the assumption x=εyx =_{\varepsilon} yx=ε​y for any x,y∈Xx,y \in Xx,y∈X at distance ε\varepsilonε. Morgan's last comment is in the right direction but you should note that this "determined by" can be quite complicated. For instance, it took us a few months to realize that one axiom we added to a theory made the metric structure collapse (i.e. all elements are at distance 0 from one another, hence the free object is a singleton space).

In the group example, I don't think 111 is at infinite distance from everything else. In deed, since 1=x⋅x−11 = x\cdot x^{-1}1=x⋅x−1 and translation is an isometry, the distance beween 111 and x⋅yx\cdot yx⋅y is equal to the distance between x−1x^{-1}x−1 and yyy. More generally, d(uxv,uyv)=d(x,y)d(uxv,uyv) = d(x,y)d(uxv,uyv)=d(x,y). Let me think more about this to find the distance (I have a hunch it will be something simple).

And yet posing d(x,1)=∞d(x,1)=\inftyd(x,1)=∞ for every xxx seems the only reasonable choice most of the times: d(x,y)≤d(x,e)+d(e,y)d(x,y)\le d(x,e) + d(e,y)d(x,y)≤d(x,e)+d(e,y), so it must be infinite when (say) the space has infinite diameter. When it does not have infinite diameter, the natural choice would be to metrize X∪{e}X \cup \{e\}X∪{e}, i.e. the disjoint union of XXX and a point that I want to use as empty word/identity element

Graev produced an example of a metric on a free group that seems to go in the right direction, but it requires you to be able to etend the metric on XXX to a metric on X∪{e}∪X−1X\cup \{e\}\cup X^{-1}X∪{e}∪X−1, see here image.png

What bothers me is that the extension of the metric on XXX to a metric on Xˉ\bar XXˉ is far from being a canonical choice: it's any metric DDD extending the one on XXX and such that D(x−1,y−1)=d(x,y)D(x^{-1},y^{-1})=d(x,y)D(x−1,y−1)=d(x,y) and D(x−1,y)=D(x,y−1)D(x^{-1},y)=D(x, y^{-1})D(x−1,y)=D(x,y−1)

in principle there might be none or many such D's and making a "trivial" choice, e.g. D(x−1,y)=∞=D(x,y−1)D(x^{-1},y)=\infty=D(x, y^{-1})D(x−1,y)=∞=D(x,y−1) trivializes everything, because D(x,y)=D(x,(y−1)−1)=∞D(x,y)=D(x, (y^{-1})^{-1})=\inftyD(x,y)=D(x,(y−1)−1)=∞...

mmh, maybe I am confused (I certainly am, I have thought about this problem for 2 days straight and I am starting to have physical pain about it!), what I mean is that in a metric group the distances d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) are fixed by the distance to/from the identity e: d(x,y)=d(xy−1,e)d(x,y)=d(xy^{-1},e)d(x,y)=d(xy−1,e) (and by the way also =d(y−1x,e)=d(y^{-1}x,e)=d(y−1x,e)), so d(x,y−1)=d(xy,e)=d(yx,e)d(x,y^{-1})=d(xy,e)=d(yx,e)d(x,y−1)=d(xy,e)=d(yx,e)

So in summary we have d(u,v)=∞d(u,v) = \inftyd(u,v)=∞ unless ℓ(u)=ℓ(v)\ell(u) = \ell(v)ℓ(u)=ℓ(v), in which case the distance is the sum of the distances between the parallel positions. Or at least that works for the free monoid construction, you probably need to check that inverses don't mess that up too much.

Yes, the free monoid is just +X+X⊗X+…+X+X\otimes X+\dots+X+X⊗X+… and on this coproduct of powers there is a canonical choice of metric: two lists are distant ∑d(xi,yi)\sum d(x_i,y_i)∑d(xi​,yi​) if they have the same length, and infinity otherwise

You still have that translations and inversion are isometries for free: translation is G→(x,id)G⊗G→⋅GG \xrightarrow{(x,id)} G\otimes G \xrightarrow{\cdot} GG(x,id)​G⊗G⋅​G and its inverse is the same with x−1x^{-1}x−1, and inversion is its own inverse.

Now for the explicit construction, we need my more recent paper which lets you require that multiplication is nonexpansive with respect to the taxicab metric. So we do have an adjoint, and we still need to characterize the distance between words (with something simpler than the logic in our paper).

I don't know about the (non-abelian) group case, but there's an analogous free construction in the linear setting: The forgetful functor from Banach spaces to pointed metric spaces has a left adjoint, known as the formation of the Arens-Eells space or Lipschitz-free space. Every pointed metric space embeds isometrically into its Arens-Eells space. See Nik Weaver's book "Lipschitz Algebras" for details, and in particular Theorem 3.6.
That's interesting, thanks. Do you believe the linear case would give some insight on how to reason more in general? I think a normed group is way more strict...

What do you mean by a normed group? If you want to require the condition that d(e,an)=nd(e,a)d(e,a^n) = n d(e,a)d(e,an)=nd(e,a), then yes, it's quite strict: DHJ Polymath proved a couple of years ago that every metric group satisfying this type of homogeneity of the metric is abelian!
and torsion free, I suppose.
Right, the groups that allow for such a metric are exactly the torsion-free abelian ones. (Where proving abelianness is the hard part.)

So as for how much the construction of the Arens-Eells space is relevant in a non-abelian setting, I'm not sure. Is the Graev metric the one which corresponds to a left adjoint from pointed metric spaces to metric groups, necessarily turning basepoints into neutral elements? In that case, I guess that this Graev metric is already strictly closer to what you want than the Arens-Eells space, right?
